case_vignette: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 2 hours. She and her husband were at the grocery store when she suddenly could not remember why she was there or how she got there. She has not had any head trauma. She has a history of depression and migraines. She does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine each night with dinner. She takes fluoxetine daily. She appears distressed and anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is fully alert and oriented to self and place but not to time. Every few minutes she asks how she got to the emergency department. She is able to follow commands and sustain attention. She recalls 3/3 objects immediately and recalls 0/3 objects at 5 minutes. The remainder of the neurological exam shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly couldn't remember why I was at the grocery store or how I got there, and now I keep asking how I got to the emergency department every few minutes.
Have you experienced any recent head injuries or changes in medications?
No, I have not had any head trauma and there have been no changes in my medications.
Do you have a history of similar episodes or any neurological conditions in the past?
I have a history of migraines, but no similar episodes like this one.
Do you have any family history of neurological diseases, such as Alzheimer's or epilepsy?
I'm not aware of any family history of neurological diseases like Alzheimer's or epilepsy.
Have you noticed any other symptoms such as headache, confusion, or problems with vision or speech, in addition to memory loss?
I appear distressed and anxious, but I have not experienced headache, problems with vision, or issues with speech.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am a 60-year-old woman.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Global Amnesia.
